Description: Neck, shoulder and body sherd (mended from numerous fragments) of Attic black-figured pottery olpe; interior: neck glazed, reserved below; exterior: glazed with shoulder area reserved (brown framing lines above and at right); black-figure decoration consisting of head, neck, part of both wings of siren or sphinx (polos, fillet necklace) facing right with wings outspread (added red on eye, hair and wings and on polos); above, black hook hanging from upper framing line; inscription on exterior.
Producer name: Attributed to the Manner of: The Gorgon Painter
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis), Well 100 (= Well 2)
Curator's comments: According to Venit, this sherd is perhaps the earliest Attic fragment found in Egypt. She also states that the polos gives the identity of the figure as a sphinx.
